Suggestions for Glenn Block – The New Client Program Product Manager of Patterns & Practices

Posted by davidhayden on April 21, 2007

Glenn is the new Product Manager responsible for the Client program of the Patterns & Practices Team. He is now looking after the Smart Client and Web Client initiatives to hopefully make sure both are addressing the needs of the developer community.


I appreciate what the Patterns & Practices Team is doing with the Smart Client and Web Client Software Factories, but I want to give Glen some constructive suggestions where the Client Program could use some improvement, especially the Web Client Software Factory. As always, I invite him to email and/or call me for more information.


One of the problems that plagues the Client Program at Patterns & Practices is that there appears to be only one team that does both the Smart Client and Web Client Software Factories. So while this development team is off developing the next release of the Smart Client Software Factory, the Web Client Software Factory is in this Monitoring Phase. A Monitoring Phase in this case means the team is off doing something else while the developer community deals with the current problems and supports itself.


Suggestion #1: Create Separate Developer Teams for Smart Client and Web Client Software Factories


Here is a suggestion I feel I shouldn’t have to mention. We need separate development teams for the Smart Client and Web Client Software Factories. This is especially important when you come out with a 1.0 or new version as you know there will be bugs that will need to be addressed immediately. In this case the Web Client Software Factory bugs are many and painful. Don’t get me started with the obvious View-Presenter Recipe and Page Flow Application Block bugs that the developer community found about 2 minutes after release. I can’t believe these bugs actually made it into the 1.0 release.


 


Suggestion #2: Get More In-Sync With Your Dependent Projects Like Enterprise Library


The Web Client Software Factory has a big dependency on Enterprise Library. I mentioned in both the Enterprise Library and Web Client Software Factory Forums WAY-IN-ADVANCE that developers will want to use the WCSF with Enterprise Library 3.0 as soon as it is released. It is also the 2nd most voted on issue in the Issue Tracker. I personally rallied as much as possible to get people to understand the importance of this issue. What did the team do? Not a damn thing. They did some smoke test that suggest you can easily use the WCSF with Ent Lib 3.0 with a simple change in references to the 3.0 assemblies. They would then come out with an official version in a month and a half. Hogwash! The answer is a half-truth as the integration requires the developer community to recompile their own version of the WCSF, re-register the guidance package, as well as painstakingly come out with new configuration files, etc. Sigh… Unless you are very familiar with Enterprise Library this is a monumental task. See Enterprise Library 3.0 and WCSF Sample Download – Can’t Wait for WCSF Team for more information on WCSF and Enterprise Library 3.0.


 


Suggestion #3: Update Your RoadMap


Update the roadmap for WCSF. If you can’t deliver a 1.1 version of the WCSF to support Enterprise Library 3.0 until mid-May, how is that deadline for the release of version 2.0 looking in June? Yep, ain’t gonna happen unless you get serious and get a separate development team working on the WCSF. You better tell us the bad news now unless you plan to pull a miracle out of your hat.


 


Suggestion #4: Publish Details About What Will Be in WCSF 2.0 Now to Get Feedback


The current proposed features for version 2.0 of the WCSF are pretty vague. I recommend publishing more detail about these proposed features immediately to get feedback from the developer community. Start tabulating issues in the issue tracker and specify what you think those customer-driven issues mean so we can make sure you are in-synch with the developer community.


 


Suggestion #5: Get the Enterprise Library Team to Publish a Maintenance Release Immediately If Necessary


Before you come out with your own 1.1 maintenance release of the WCSF that supports Ent Lib 3.0 and includes your own big fixes, I recommend getting the Enterprise Library Development Team to come out with a maintenance release of Enterprise Library if necessary. I can’t be sure since there is no known issues list for Enterprise Library 3.0, but there seems to be an unusual number of bugs being detected early in the latest release of Enterprise Library 3.0 that is out of character for the Enterprise Library Team. I found one personally in the Policy Injection Application Block and I have seen a few others mentioned in the forums. At least consult with them to make sure they won’t be coming out with a maintenance release immediately and we again have this dependency issue.


 


Again, I like the deliverables coming out of the Patterns & Practices Team, but nobody is perfect and I hope they take these suggestions seriously. Glenn, feel free to call me for more information as I deal with this stuff daily.


by David Hayden

    I read my post again and that was just a poorly written suggestion. It did sound like I was lobbying for a maintenance release when what I was really suggesting was making sure we didn’t have a new version of WCSF released that supported Ent Lib 3.0 only to have an Ent Lib 3.1 to come out immediately.

  3. David Hayden says:
    April 22, 2007 at 5:37 pm

    Hey Tom,

    I wasn’t lobbying for a maintenance release of Enterprise Library. I just wanted to make sure Glenn worked with you guys to verify you weren’t coming out with a maintenance release before he came out with a version of WCSF that supports 3.0.

  4. Tom Hollander says:
    April 22, 2007 at 4:49 pm

    Thanks for setting Glenn to work right away Dave
    One quick comment – you don’t need to go through Glenn to lobby for an EntLib 3.0 maintenance release, since you know how to find me. We’re planning a minor bugfix release now that we’ll try to get released as quickly as possible. We’ll provide more details once our plans are more concrete.

    Tom

  5. David Hayden says:
    April 22, 2007 at 1:32 pm

    Hi Glenn,

    I understand the importance of using your resources wisely, but effectively you are saying the same thing – due to limited resources you don’t have a team that is dedicated to the WCSF. This means the product sits in this wait mode for a few months until we can get someone to fix the list of problems that plague the developer community as well as add support quickly to community-demanded, high priority requests like Ent Lib 3.0.

    Waiting wouldn’t be such a big deal except the product is fraught with bugs, requiring several workarounds that include a number of modifications to the guidance package. For Enterprise Library 3.0 support we need to create our own compiled version and still have issues using it because there are features in the current WCSF that are broken and cause us to manually deal with things ( The broken Locate Enterprise Library Assemblies Wizard comes to mind ).

    The current support team is not solving problems but merely pushing out the same old tired workarounds or saying “wait for 1.1″, and some like the View-Presenter Problem keeps raising it’s ugly head even after the so-called “fix” has been applied.

    We needed a maintenance release over a month ago to fix all the bugs, and we should have had a specific version for Ent Lib 3.0 right after it was released because the community vocalized this need way in advance.

    That is all past us now, however, and I think you can see where the process could have been better. The key now is just to get a 1.1 version out immediately that fixes the current bugs and supports Ent Lib 3.0.

    I look forward to you contacting me to discuss this further if you wish. Thanks for listening.

  6. Glenn Block says:
    April 22, 2007 at 3:48 am

    I forgot to add. We actually do have a dedicated support engineering team whose job is to support our client products full time. So for example while SCSF is in development, that team is there to ensure that we help our customers and provide fixes for bugs discovered in our release buils.

  7. Glenn Block says:
    April 22, 2007 at 3:35 am

    Hi David

    Thanks for your feedback. I will certainly take everything you are saying here into consideration concerning WCSF and SCSF. I will also take you up and your offer and follow up with you directly

    We do have separate teams that developer Smart Client and WCSF. However these teams do not operate in parrallel. Within p&p we have to use our resources in the most optimal fashion. Based on that we only have a set of major projects that are in development at any one time.

    Currently for example in the factory space we have the WSSF and SCSF in dev. Shortly SCSF next release will be completed, and we will regroup resources to form a new team for WCSF. As to synching between the product teams, i.e. Entlib with SCSF / WCSF, this is certainly something we try to do, but we can always do better.

    I really like your ideas about roadmap visibility and including the community as early in the process as possbile, which means in the planning phase. You will see a concerted effort on my part to be as open as I can (without violoating any legal constraints) to both share our ideas of what we think we should be building, as well as incorporate you feedback and suggestions.

    Thanks
